For the purposes of this map, developed land cover includes a variety of development, such as single family homes, multifamily housing units, retail, commercial, industrial sites, and associated infrastructure. Developed land cover is not confined to city limits.
layer.name: Percent developed area

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is frequently or periodically wet due to high water accumulation and has been developed or urbanized for 2006-2010. This map uses a wetness index of 550 from a compound topographic index (CTI) to determine if the area is considered to be wet. This map includes various types of development such as open spaces, parks, golf courses, single family homes, multifamily housing units, retail, commercial, industrial sites, and associated infrastructure.

fieldInfos.label: Percent developed land in areas of high water accumulation

layer.name: Percent developed land in areas of high water accumulation

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the percent of land comprised of emergent herbaceous wetlands in each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. For this map, EnviroAtlas uses the National Land Cover Database and its definition of  emergent herbaceous wetlands.
layer.name: Percent emergent herbaceous wetlands

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percentage of total land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is covered by trees and forest for 2011.
layer.name: Percent forest

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percentage of total land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is covered by trees and forest or woody wetlands for 2011. EnviroAtlas uses the National Land Cover Database definition of woody wetlands.
layer.name: Percent forest and woody wetlands

layer.eaDescription: This map layer portrays the percent of land within 30 meters of streams, rivers, and other hydrologically connected waterbodies within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is covered by trees and forests or woody wetlands for 2006. EnviroAtlas uses the 2006 National Land Cover Database definition of woody wetlands.

fieldInfos.label: Percent forest and woody wetlands in stream buffer

layer.name: Percent forest and woody wetlands in stream buffer

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is frequently or periodically wet due to high water accumulation and is covered by trees and forests for 2006-2010. This map uses a wetness index of 550 from a compound topographic index (CTI) to determine if the area is considered to be wet.

fieldInfos.label: Percent forest in areas with high water accumulation

layer.name: Percent forest in areas with high water accumulation

layer.eaDescription: This map layer portrays the percent of land within 30 meters of streams, rivers, and other hydrologically connected waterbodies within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is covered by trees and forests for 2006.

fieldInfos.label: Percent forest land in stream buffer

layer.name: Percent forest land in stream buffer

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has legally recognized easements for conservation or other protections in place to restrict human use or development for 2011. This layer includes both public and private land.
layer.name: Percent GAP status 1 and 2

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has legally recognized easements for conservation or other protections in place to restrict human use or development for 2011. This layer includes both public and private land.
layer.name: Percent GAP status 1, 2, and 3

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is designated as Status 3 under the USGS Gap Analysis Program for 2011. These areas have permanent protection from conversion of natural land cover for the majority of area. Subject to extractive uses of either broad, low-intensity type (e.g.. Logging) or localized intense type (e.g.. Mining). Confers protection to federally listed endangered and threatened species throughout the area.
layer.name: Percent GAP status 3

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of total land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is impervious for 2006. Impervious surfaces do not allow the penetration of water and include buildings, roads, and sidewalks.
layer.name: Percent impervious area

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status IA by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category IA protected areas seek to protect biodiversity and natural features; human visitation, use, and impacts are strictly controlled.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status IA

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status IB by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category IB protected areas include large unmodified or slightly modified areas, without permanent or significant human habitation. These lands are protected and managed so as to protect their natural condition.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status IB

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status II by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category II protected areas re large natural or near natural areas set aside to protect large-scale ecological processes, along with the complement of species and ecosystems characteristic of the area, which also provide a foundation for environmentally and culturally compatible, spiritual, scientific, educational, recreational, and visitor opportunities.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status II

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status III by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category III protected areas are set aside to protect a specific natural monument, which can be a landform, sea mount, submarine cavern, geological feature such as a cave or even a living feature such as an ancient grove. They are generally quite small protected areas and often have high visitor value.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status III

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status IV by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category IV areas aim to protect particular species or habitats and management reflects this priority. Many Category IV protected areas will need regular, active interventions to address the requirements of particular species or to maintain habitats, but this is not a requirement of the category.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status IV

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status V by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category V protected areas have distinct character with significant, ecological, biological, cultural and scenic value: and where safeguarding the integrity of this interaction is vital to protecting and sustaining the area and its associated nature conservation and other values.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status V

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status VI by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category VI protected areas are generally large, with most of the area in a natural condition, where a proportion is under sustainable natural resource management and where low-level non-industrial use of natural resources compatible with nature conservation is seen as one of the main aims of the area.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status VI

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is protected. It includes all lands that have been classified by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as protected areas for 2011.

fieldInfos.label: Percent land with any IUCN status

layer.name: Percent land with any IUCN status

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within each subwatershed that is covered by large patches of natural areas for 2006-2010. Large natural areas are greater than 25,000 acres and covered by forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, or wetlands. It excludes areas that are covered by agriculture and developed land.

fieldInfos.label: Percent large size patches of natural land cover

layer.name: Percent large size patches of natural land cover

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within each subwatershed that is covered by medium sized patches of natural areas for 2006-2010. Medium natural areas are less 25,000 acres but greater than 500 acres and are covered by forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, or wetlands. It excludes areas that are covered by agriculture and developed land.

fieldInfos.label: Percent medium size patches of natural land cover

layer.name: Percent medium size patches of natural land cover

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of total land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has natural land cover for 2011. Natural land cover includes forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, and wetlands; it excludes agriculture and impervious surfaces.
layer.name: Percent natural land cover

layer.eaDescription: This map layer portrays the percent of naturally covered land within 30 meters of streams, rivers, and other hydrologically connected waterbodies within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2006. Natural land cover includes forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, and wetlands; it excludes agriculture and developed land.

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within each subwatershed that is covered by small patches of natural areas for 2006-2010. Small natural areas are less 500 acres and covered by forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, or wetlands. It excludes areas that are covered by agriculture and developed land.

fieldInfos.label: Percent small size patches of natural land cover

layer.name: Percent small size patches of natural land cover

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is frequently or periodically wet due to high water accumulation and is covered by wetlands for 2006-2010. layer.eaDescription: The EnviroAtlas Potential Wetland Areas (PWA) dataset shows potential wetland areas at 30-meter resolution. Beginning two centuries ago, many wetlands were turned into farm fields or urban areas, yet wetlands play an important role in removing water pollution, regulating water storage and flows, and providing habitat for wildlife. Wetland restoration could help restore these benefits. Potential wetland areas, as developed for this map, are lands that naturally accumulate water due to topography and have historically had poorly or very poorly draining soils. This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to the EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).

layer.eaDescription: This map for rare ecosystems in the conterminous U.S. delineates the Relative Rarity Metric developed by the EPA. The metric is based on current extent, spatial pattern type, and relative uniqueness. Metric values range from 0 to 100 with higher values indicating greater relative ecosystem rarity.

General Agency Level (Land Stewardship)

layer.eaDescription: NLCD (National Land Cover Database) classifications are based primarily on Landsat data along with ancillary data sources, such as topography, census and agricultural statistics, soil characteristics, wetlands, and other land cover maps. NLCD 2011 is a 16-class land cover classification scheme that has been applied consistently across the conterminous U.S. at a spatial resolution of 30 meters. For additional information, go to https://www.mrlc.gov/. See https://viewer.nationalmap.gov/help for assistance with The National Map viewer, services, or metadata.
layer.name: National Land Cover Database (NLCD 1992 - 2011)

layer.eaDescription: This category contains a map of a variable from the U.S. Natural Resources Conservation Service's soils dataset, called SSURGO (Soil Survey Geographic Database), that contains all variables found in county soil surveys. The SSURGO variable natural drainage class (dominant condition) was selected for use in EnviroAtlas because it indicates soil wetness or degree of saturation.
layer.name: Soils Drainage Class - dominant condition

layer.eaDescription: These maps identify waterbodies that have been assessed and determined to be impaired, meaning that the waterbody has been degraded and does not meet the standards for seven designated beneficial uses (such as aquatic life habitat, drinking water supply, and fish consumption). This map identifies area features from the Impaired Waters database.
layer.name: Impaired Waters

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts waterbodies that have been assessed by states, territories, and authorized tribes every two years to evaluate waterbody condition for seven beneficial uses (such as aquatic life habitat, drinking water supply, and fish consumption). Those waterbodies not meeting the standards for beneficial uses are designated as impaired or threatened. This map identifies area features from the Assessed Waters database.
layer.name: Assessed Waters

layer.eaDescription: This National Wetlands Inventory (NWI) map, developed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, maps and classifies wetlands across the U.S. State and local government agencies use NWI in planning to identify local wetlands and to limit and mitigate wetland losses during economic development.
layer.name: Wetlands

layer.eaDescription: This dataset contains polygons and points representing the location of markets and projects primarily targeting watershed-related ecosystem services per Ecosystem Marketplace research. Polygons for projects represent the project footprint (i.e. land area comprising the project site) or area of primary impact. Polygons for markets represent the entire region that shares market infrastructure and rules, or a larger program encompassing many smaller projects. Points represent the centroids of market and project polygons with the exception of national markets, whose points represent administrative headquarters locations.
layer.name: Watersheds - Projects and Markets

layer.eaDescription: This dataset contains polygons and points representing the location of markets and projects primarily targeting imperiled species and/or habitat ecosystem services per USACE RIBITS data and Ecosystem Marketplace research. Polygons for projects represent the project footprint (i.e. land area comprising the project site) or area of primary impact. Polygons for markets represent the entire region that shares market infrastructure and rules, or a larger program encompassing many smaller projects, such as habitat exchanges. Points represent the centroids of market and project polygons with the exception of national markets, whose points represent administrative headquarters locations.
layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitats - Projects and Markets

Points represent the centroids of market and project polygons with the exception of national markets, whose points represent administrative headquarters locations.

Polygons for markets represent the entire region that shares market infrastructure and rules, or a larger program encompassing many smaller projects. layer.eaDescription: This dataset contains polygons representing guidance, enabling policies, and regulatory drivers that facilitate ecosystem services markets per Ecosystem Marketplace research. It includes conditions that specifically establish ecosystem market mechanisms, as well as conditions that indirectly function as the regulatory driver for ecosystem markets. Data cover watershed, Imperiled Species and Habitats, wetland and streams, and forest carbon asset types. Scales represented include watershed (HUC8), state, regional, national, and federal lands.
layer.name: Enabling Conditions

layer.eaDescription: These maps portray carbon removed annually from the atmosphere and sequestered in the above-ground biomass of trees in each census block group as Total (mt/yr) or Value ($/yr).
layer.name: Carbon sequestered by tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps portray carbon stored in the above-ground biomass of trees by census block group as Total (mt/yr) or Value ($/yr).
layer.name: Carbon stored by tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict cotton (Yields, Hectares, Value) grown annually within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2007-2010.
layer.name: Cotton Crops

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict fruit crops (Yields, Hectares, Number) grown annually within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2010.
layer.name: Fruit Crops

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict major grain crops (Yields, Hectares, Number, Value) grown annually within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2007-2010.
layer.name: Grain Crops

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict vegetable crops (Yields, Hectares, Number) grown annually within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2010.
layer.name: Vegetable Crops

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the population (number of people or percent) that resides within 500 meters of a park entrance in each census block group.
layer.name: Residential population not within 500m of a park entrance

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the population (number of people or percent) with less than 5 percent tree cover within 50 meters of their home.
layer.name: Residential population with minimal views of trees

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the population (number of people or percent) in each census block group that may have a view of water within 50 meters of their home. These maps includes streams, lakes, rivers, and coastal waters.
layer.name: Residential population with  views of water

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the population (number of people or percent) that resides within 500 meters of a park entrance in each census block group.
layer.name: Residential population within 500m of a park entrance

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the annual asthma exacerbation cases that may be avoided due to total nitrogen dioxide removed by trees in each census block group as Total (cases/yr) or Value ($/yr).
layer.name: Asthma exacerbation avoided due to nitrogen dioxide removed by tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the annual asthma exacerbation cases that may be avoided due to total sulfur dioxide removed by trees in each census block group as Total (cases/yr) or Value ($/yr).
layer.name: Asthma exacerbation avoided due to sulfur dioxide removed by tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the annual school days that may not be lost to illness due to total ozone removed by trees in each census block group as Total (days/yr) or Value ($/yr).
layer.name: School days not lost to illness due to ozone removed by tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the land covered by impervious surfaces within (15 or 50) meters of hydrologically connected non-coastal waters in each census block group. Impervious surfaces are materials that do not allow the penetration of water and include buildings, roads, and sidewalks.
layer.name: Percent impervious area in stream and lake buffer

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the percent land in each census block group that is within (15 or 50) meters of hydrologically connected non-coastal waters.
layer.name: Percent land area in stream and lake buffer

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the percent land covered by trees within (15 or 50) meters of hydrologically connected non-coastal waters in each census block group.
layer.name: Percent tree cover in stream and lake buffer

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the percent land covered by vegetation within (15 or 50) meters of hydrologically connected non-coastal waters in each census block group.
layer.name: Percent vegetated cover in stream and lake buffer

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the square meters of land within (15 or 50) meters of hydrologically connected non-coastal waters in each census block group.
layer.name: Total land area in stream and lake buffer

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the percent tree cover within (15 or 50) meters of hydrologically connected non-coastal waters. It is not summarized by census block group.
layer.name: Estimated tree cover in stream and lake buffer (percent)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the percent vegetated cover within (15 or 50) meters of hydrologically connected non-coastal waters. It is not summarized by census block group.
layer.name: Estimated vegetated cover in stream and lake buffer (percent)

layer.eaDescription: Percentage of stream and water body shoreline lengths having impervious cover greater than or equal to 5% or 15% within 30 meters for 2011.
layer.name: Percent of stream and shoreline with percent or more impervious cover within 30 meters

layer.eaDescription: These maps model the diversity of land cover types within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the SE or SW GAP regions  for 2013. The mean value is the average number of land cover types found within 1 kilometer of any given point in the subwatershed, the maximum value is the greatest number of land cover types found within 1 kilometer of any given point in the subwatershed , and the index value is based on average values determined for each HUC.
layer.name: Land cover diversity

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the percent of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that could be classified as rare ecosystem forms or rare ecosystems forms protected for 2011. Ecosystem rarity in EnviroAtlas is based on size, shape, and type of ecosystem.
layer.name: Rare ecosystem forms

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the ambient carbon monoxide (total kilograms or mean percent) removed annually by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Carbon monoxide removed annually by tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the nitrogen dioxide (total kilograms or mean percent) removed annually by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Nitrogen dioxide removed annually by tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the ozone (total kilograms or mean percent) removed annually by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Ozone removed annually by tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the particulate matter greater than 2.5 microns but less than 10 microns (total kilograms or mean percent) removed annually by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Particulate matter [PM10] removed annually by tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the particulate matter less than 2.5 microns (total kilograms or mean percent) removed annually by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Particulate matter [PM2.5] removed annually by tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the sulfur dioxide (total kilograms or mean percent) removed annually by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Sulfur dioxide removed annually by tree cover

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the (mean or median) reduction in biochemical oxygen demand (kg/yr) in streamflow due to filtration by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Reduction in biochemical oxygen demand [BOD5] due to tree cover (kg/yr)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the (mean or median) reduction in chemical oxygen demand (kg/yr) in streamflow due to filtration from trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Reduction in chemical oxygen demand [COD] due to tree cover (kg/yr)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the (mean or median) reduction in load of copper (kg/yr) in streamflow due to filtration by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Reduction in load of copper due to tree cover (kg/yr)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the (mean or median) reduction in load of nitrites and nitrates (kg/yr) in streamflow due to filtration by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Reduction in load of nitrites and nitrates due to tree cover (kg/yr)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the (mean or median) reduction in load of soluble phosphorus (kg/yr) in streamflow due to filtration by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Reduction in load of soluble phosphorus due to tree cover (kg/yr)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the (mean or median) reduction in load of total Kjeldahl nitrogen (kg/yr) in streamflow due to filtration by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Reduction in load of total Kjeldahl nitrogen [TKN] due to tree cover (kg/yr)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the (mean or median) reduction in load of total phosphorus (kg/yr) in streamflow due to filtration by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Reduction in load of total phosphorus due to tree cover (kg/yr)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the (mean or median) reduction in load of total suspended solids (kg/yr) in streamflow due to filtration by trees in each census block group.
layer.name: Reduction in load of total suspended solids [TSS] due to tree cover (kg/yr)

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict the mean rate of biological nitrogen fixation from either the cultivation of crops or in natural and semi-natural ecosystems within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kg N/ha/yr for 2006.
layer.name: Biological nitrogen fixation (kg N/ha/yr)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the annual deposition of oxidized nitrogen within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. Wet deposition occurs when rain, snow, or fog carry nitrogen to the earth’s surface, dry deposition occurs when particles or gases attach to surfaces such as dust or smoke and fall to the earth's surface, and total includes both dry and wet deposition.
layer.name: Annual oxidized nitrogen deposition (kg/ha)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the annual deposition of reduced nitrogen within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. Wet deposition occurs when rain, snow, or fog carry nitrogen to the earth’s surface, dry deposition occurs when particles or gases attach to surfaces such as dust or smoke and fall to the earth's surface, and total includes both dry and wet deposition.
layer.name: Annual reduced nitrogen deposition (kg/ha)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the annual deposition of sulfur within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. Wet deposition occurs when rain, snow, or fog carry sulfur to the earth’s surface, dry deposition occurs when particles or gases attach to surfaces such as dust or smoke and fall to the earth's surface, and total includes both dry and wet deposition.
layer.name: Annual sulfur deposition (kg/ha)

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict bird species richness for bird species listed by Partners in Flight in their Watch List for a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US for 2015 as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Modeled Partners in Flight Watch List bird species

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict bird species richness for Birds of Conservation Concern for a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US for 2015 as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations. The Bird of Conservation Concern Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area.
layer.name: Modeled State of the Birds species of conservation concern

layer.eaDescription: These maps depict threatened and endangered species richness for a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the SE or SW GAP regions  for 2013 as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These maps is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Modeled threatened and endangered vertebrate species

layer.eaDescription: These maps model Audubon Climate Endangered bird species (https://climate.audubon.org/) that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US for 2015  as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These are bird species vulnerable to a loss of 50% or more of current range due to climate change by 2050. These maps is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Number of bird species vulnerable to range loss due to climate change by 2050

layer.eaDescription: These maps model Audubon Climate Threatened bird species (https://climate.audubon.org/) that are likely to be present in any single location within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in the Conterminous US for 2015 as the maximum, mean, or NIB (index). These are bird species vulnerable to a loss of 50% or more of current range due to climate change by 2080. These maps is based on habitat models, not wildlife observations.
layer.name: Number of bird species vulnerable to range loss due to climate change by 2080

layer.eaDescription: These maps illustrates the number of species (Animal, Plant, Total) associated with aquatic habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011.
layer.name: Number of at-risk aquatic species

layer.eaDescription: These maps illustrates the number of species (Animal, Plant, Total) associated with terrestrial habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. G1 and G2 denote Global Conservation Ranks classified by NatureServe. Terrestrial habitat refers to land areas such as forests, grasslands, deserts and rainforests.
layer.name: Number of at-risk terrestrial species

layer.eaDescription: These maps illustrates the number of species (Animal, Plant, Total) associated with wetland habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. G1 and G2 denote Global Conservation Ranks classified by NatureServe.
layer.name: Number of at-risk wetland species

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the average reduction in the ambient temperature at 2pm on a hot summer day (daytime) or  at night following a hot summer day (nighttime) due to the cooling properties of tree cover in each census block group.
layer.name: Average reduction in ambient temperature (Celsius)

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the population (total or percent) within each census block group that resides within 300 meters of a busy roadway. A “busy” roadway in EnviroAtlas is defined to include interstates, arterial roads, and collector roads. It does not include local or neighborhood roads, though some of these roads may also experience consistent and heavy traffic.
layer.name: Residential population within 300m of busy roadway

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the total population within each census block group that resides within 300 meters of a busy roadway that is buffered by less than 25 percent or greater than 25 percent tree cover within 26 meters of a road edge. A “busy” roadway in EnviroAtlas is defined to include interstates, arterial roads, and collector roads. It does not include local or neighborhood roads, though some of these roads may also experience consistent and heavy traffic.
layer.name: Residential population within 300m of busy roadway with &#119987 percent tree buffer

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the percent of busy roadway in each census block group that  is bordered by less than 25 percent or greater than 25 percent tree cover within 26 meters of a road edge. A “busy” roadway in  EnviroAtlas is defined to include interstates, arterial roads, and collector roads. It does not include local or neighborhood roads, though some of these roads may also experience consistent and heavy traffic.
layer.name: Percent of busy roadway bordered by &#119987 percent tree buffer

layer.eaDescription: These maps estimate the reduction in surface runoff as (m3/yr) or percent each year within each census block group due to the presence of trees.
layer.name: Reduction in annual runoff due to tree cover
